1) Number of and effectiveness of recovery (rehabilitation and reconstruction) partnership and coordination mechanisms among GoI agencies, CSOs, public and private sector organizations and local communities.
2) Extent to which the process of strengthening the GoIâ€™s institutional system for rehabilitation and reconstruction has been documented and made available throughout Indonesia, and at the regional and global levels.

comment.narrative:
1) Existence of a recovery partnership and coordination mechanism as guided by the RRG 2010, which includes the enactment and implantation of a comprehensive post-disaster, needs assessment guideline in 2011, i.e., Indonesia Post Disaster Needs Assessment (I-PDNA). The existence of the platform for facilitating and financing expedited disaster recovery response involving international community was established in 2011 i.e., the Multi Donor Fund Facility for Disaster Recovery (IMDFFDR); and existence of UNDP Surge mechanism to support GoI in ensuring early recovery needs and interventions to take place immediately after a disaster.
2) Lessons learned in the context of post disaster recovery coordination and programming mechanism has not yet been fully documented

description.narrative: Undertake livelihood recovery needs assessments and develop strategy for rapid livelihood recovery.
first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: The project locations are PIdie, Pidie Jaya and Bireuen Districts that are part of Aceh Province government administration. The three districts were affected by an earthquake disaster in December 2016 and upon request by the Government of Indonesia, the project provides livelihood recovery assessmen

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1. # of local BPPDs in disaster affected areas supported; based on the request of GoI, to undertake recovery coordination for need assessment/recovery planning/implementation/monitoring.
2. The extent to which direct recovery response has addressed the selected most priority needs in the scope of governance, livelihoods, community infrastructure, debris clearance and management, environment, risk reduction, and social cohesion (GLIDERS), which are gender sensitive

comment.narrative: 1. The government Action plan for Rehabilitation and Reconstruction in Pidie only prioritise physical infrastructure. 2. In-depth analysis of critically affected sector(s) is needed to complement the government action plan for recovery. 3. Request from BNPB to UNDP to undertake livelihood recovery
N/A
N/A
N/A
N/A
At least 3 (three) Districts Government BPBDs assisted to undertake livelihood recovery assessment.

1. Livelihood Recovery Assessment undertaken in three districts i.e. Pidie, Pidie Jaya and Bireuen, affected by the eartquake. Priorities were envisaged on agriculture sector that has potential to recover swiftly compared with other community income generation activities.
2. Data collection processes were conducted for 20 days. 352 respondents were interviewed, 39 respondents from 14 sub-districts and 32 villages in Pidie, 273 families from 6 sub-districts and 129 villages in Pidie Jaya and 40 respondents from 21 villages in 2 sub-districts in Bireuen.
3. Value chain analysis consultants have interviewed 57 different actors whom involved in cocoa productions, including government officers, farmers, traders, cooperatives, supplier and tradersâ€™ and farmersâ€™ associations.
4. The analysis has concluded that intervention on cocoa production in the affected district will stimulate and accelerate the recovery of community livelihood and local economy. Post-Data Collection follow up actions have been agreed with district level and provincial level BPBDs such as Province level dissemination and recovery planning strategy and National level dissemination and coordination
5. Formulation of livelihood recovery strategy. The finalisation is expected to be completed in December 2017.

comment.narrative:
4 formulated policies
1 Draft policy on wind power Feedin Tariff FIT
2 Draft National standard on Design requirements for small wind turbines IEC614002 Persyaratan Rancangan Turbin Angin Skala Kecil
3 Draft National Standard on Power Performance measurements of electricity producing wind turbines IEC61400121 Pengukuran unjuk kerja daya lisrik yang dihasilkan oleh turbin angina
4 Draft national standard on Measurement and assessment of Power quality characteristic of connected wind turbines IEC 6140021 Pengukuran dan pengkajian karakteristik kualitas daya pada koneksi ke grid turbin angin
To support the formulation of wind project permitting process the project conducted a capacity building program that involved local governments that has potential wind energy in their region The activity was mainly to give better understanding on the wind project development process and stages It is expected that through this program the central government and the local government will have equal understanding on their role and involvement in the process Furthermore the result of the program can also serve as an input in formulating a detail regulation on the permitting process of wind project especially for a large scale wind farm

Currently MEMR is setting up the required rooms hardware and software Based on the discussion with MEMR WHyPGen Project will be asked to provide all the related information on wind energy project to support the clearing house ie wind potential data list of available technology supplier local manufacturer and other supporting documents Currently with the data from WHyPGen submitted on Feb 2014 MEMR with support from ESP3 program from the Danish government had developed wind potential map in a meso scale However the wind map was limited only to the Sumatera Island some parts of Java and Sulawesi island WHyPGen Project will develop Indonesia wind map in micro scale

Hydrochlorofluorocarbons (HCFC) Phase-out Management Plan (HPMP) for compliance with the 2013 and 2015 control targets for Annex-C, Group-I substances (HCFCs) in Indonesia.
Hydrochlorofluorocarbons (HCFC) Phase-out Management Plan (HPMP), for compliance with the 2013 and 2015 control targets for HCFC consumption according to the Montreal Protocol.
capital of a political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration
Availability of policies/ technical guidelines/ strategies and mechanisms on HCFC reduction programme; and % reduction of HCFC consumption.

comment.narrative: In 2009, the consumption of HCFC-141b = 1,186 metric tonnes (MT) or 130.5 ODP tonnes; HCFC-22 = 4,327MT or 237.9 ODP T; HCFC-123 = 318MT or 6.4 ODP T; HCFC-225 =1MT or 0 ODP T. In total = 403.9 ODP tonnes

As a result of the implementation of HCFC licensing and quota system and conversion projects, the consumption of all HCFCs used in the country has decreased in 2015. The (verified) 2015 consumption of 152.67 ODP tonnes of HCFCs was 58 per cent below the 2015 allowable consumption and 62 per cent below Indonesiaâ€™s baseline of 403.9 ODP tonnes.
Verified report on the consumption of HCFCs in Indonesia; and reduced HCFCs consumption against the baseline established by Montreal Protocol

(1) The verification report confirmed that the Government has an enforceable licensing and quota system for HCFC imports and that the total consumption of HCFCs was 310.5 ODP tonnes in 2013; (2) 258 ODP tonnes in 2014, and 152.67 ODP tonnes in 2015. (3) The verification concluded that Indonesia has met the Montreal Protocol targets for the relevant years; (4) The Government of Indonesia reported HCFC sector consumption data under the 2014 CP implementation report which is consistent with the data reported under Article 7. The 2015 CP report was submitted on 1 May 2016. (5) The licensing and quota system for HCFC imports was established in 2012 and further updated in October of 2015. The Government has issued HCFC import quotas for 2015 and 2016 at 269.4 ODP tonnes. (6) The Government has prohibited the use of HCFC-22 and HCFC-141b in RAC manufacturing and assembly sectors from 1 January 2015; and has removed HFC-32 from the list of highly flammable substances and is developing standards for its safe use in RAC equipment. The enterprises manufacturing HFC-32-based products have their own safety standards in installing and servicing the equipment. Currently, there is no regulation restricting the import of products/substances with high GWP.
Validated consumption on HCFCs untl 2017 in compliance with Montreal Protocol; and reduced consumption against the baseline; Promoted MAWAS apps to monitor HCFCs consumption at the field level

(1) In the air-conditioning manufacturing sector, out of 21 enterprises, five enterprises completed their conversion to HFC-32, with a total phase-out of 353.46 mt (19.44 ODP tonnes) of HCFC-22. In the commercial refrigeration sector, out of 27 enterprises, 15 enterprises had stopped using HCFCs and are expected to finalize their conversion to HFC-32 to replace 127.1 mt (6.99 ODP tonnes) of HCFC-22 refrigerant and cyclopentane to replace 413 mt (45.43 ODP tonnes) of HCFC-141b as a foam blowing agent by mid-2016. (2) The phase-out activity to address HCFC consumption in the servicing sector was limited to the establishment of a product stewardship programme for management of refrigerants, reclaim equipment supply for demonstration purposes and an awareness programme (as a bilateral cooperation by the Government of Australia). As of September 2015, manuals on good service practices and on use of flammable refrigerants in refrigeration and air-conditioning (RAC) equipment had been translated, and consultations with the Management Refrigeration Association of Indonesia (AMRI) on phase-out related matters in the RAC sector had been carried out. (3) MAWAS apps has been promoted to servicing sector.

Output 2) Livelihoods of vulnerable rural communities strengthened in a changing climate. 2.1. Number of communities have developed a community based climate risk information system 2.2. description.narrative: To enable the NTT province to strengthen climate resilience of its rural Communities to improve livelihood food and water security
Annual Provincial and District government Work Plans and budgets approved by provincial and district parliaments that include specific reference to adaptation actions refer to AMAT 1111

comment.narrative: Climate change is not integrated in provincial budgets and district budgets The provincial Medium term development plan does not include any reference to climate change
budget allocation for adaptation actions in the Provincial Annual Work Plan and in the Annual Work Plans of at least three districts from 2014 onward

The Project Objective has been partially achieved supported by following important building blocks that has been put in place to enable mainstreaming CCA in development planning and budgeting of NTT province and pilot districts by the end of the project
Inclusion of climate change adaptation as one of priority issues in NTT Provincial Medium Term Development Plan 20132019 Regional Regulation No12014 has established a legal basis for planning and budget allocation for CCA in provincial district to village level
A village level Climate vulnerability and risk map for NTT province has been adopted by provincial and district development planning agency Bappeda as one of development planning references to inform locations and designing adaptation programme The map has been distributed by provincial Bappeda to all districts in NTT province
The project provided in depth technical assistance to related sectors in provincial and district governments such as agency of Agriculture Food Security Meteorology Environment Public Work and Bappeda in planning CCA programme for 2015 and 2016 work plan
As a result CCArelated activities such as water pond construction rehabilitation of irrigation system and improvement of rice variety have been included and budgeted in the 2015 work plan of the following sectoral government agencies in three district and provinces Agency of Agriculture and Plantation Food Security the Forest Service Department of Agriculture and Horticulture Department of Public Works Environment the Regional Disaster Management Office of Cooperative and Small and Medium Enterprises Maritime Affairs and Fisheries
In the rest of the project lifecycle these activities need to be monitored and their effectiveness validated in terms of their relevance to identified climate risks and vulnerability in targeted locations to differentiate the CCA with BusinessAsUsual development activities

description.narrative: Institutional capacity developed to integrate climate resilience in sustainable development at provincial and district level
disaggregated by gender number of trained people mandated to support climate resilient planning

comment.narrative: no trained people mandated
at least 100 trained people are mandated to support climate resilient planning

During this reporting period a total of 229 individuals 189 male and 40 female have been engaged various capacity building trainings including the following
Training on CCA action plan and institutional work plan formulation targeting the following agencies from three district and Province Bappeda Public Work Environment Agriculture and Plantation Food Security Extension Food Crop Forestry Fishery and Coastal BPTP UNDANA University Cooperative and small scale business 34 male 14 female
Training of Trainers on Climate Field School for district agencies and agricultural extension workers of the project pilot districts 17 male 2 female Provincial agencies and UNDANA were invited as the resource agencies
Technical training for village facilitators extension workers in three pilot Districts 92 male 16 female This training focused on developing skill of field facilitators in advocating for integrating CCA activities in villages sub district and districts development work plan
Training for local journalists on the climate change issues its impacts on development and rural communities and how to communicate it for public 46 male 8 female The trainer was an eminent environmental journalist from Kompas a national newspaper
In addition to these trainings the SPARC project initiated institutional support in the area of data management that contribute to the overall institutional capacity for integrating climate resilience in subnational development planning Through SPARC support Bappeda and Stats Agency developed an online meta data system called NTT Satu Data NTT One Data which uses not just data from the Stats Dept but also data collected through the SPARCled vulnerability assessment and village socioeconomic assessment It is expected to complement SIDIK System Informasi Data Index Vulnerability which is hosted at MoEF and contains a range of information including sitespecific vulnerability and adaptation options The information in NTT Satu Data and SIDIK is expected to contribute to an improved decision making and development planning at all levels

description.narrative: number and type of provincial and district level policies and programmes which have been adjusted issued to address climate change resilience

comment.narrative: No integration of climate resilience in provincial and district policies and programmes
climate change resilience has been integrated in at least NTTs Medium Term Development Plan 20142018 and policies and programmes on agriculture and water

This indicator was achieved during the current reporting period
NTTs Medium Term Development Plan RPJMD 20132018 is based on Regional Regulation No 1 of 2014 and mentions specifically that CC mitigation and adaptation as one of strategic issues that the province has to consider In particular they are referenced under Mission 5 Accelerate the development of infrastructure based on spatial allocation and environmental considerations Priority Program to establish an information and communication system to improve the resilience of communities to climate change Indicators 1 Total forest that can be managed by communities as part of climate mitigation and adaptation and 2 Plan for responses to disasters and climate change starting at the village level
In addition Governor regulation No292014 on Government Work Plan 2014 RKPD 2014 has stated Priority Programme on CC mitigation and adaptation with targets 23 of total forest area managed by communities and 22 districts have developed disaster and climate change action plan

description.narrative: number and type of targeted institutions with increased adaptive capacity to minimize exposure to climate variability describe number and time refer to AMAT 221

comment.narrative: no systematic institutional capacity development for adaptation is ongoing
At least 5 institutes have strengthened their systems programmes and human resources to better address climate variability

Based on the identified climate risks and required CCA actions the project focused on the following institutions those have authority and responsibility for implementing CCA actions in provincial and district level Bappeda BMKG BPTP Regional disaster management agency Public Work Environment agency Agriculture Plantation and Livestock agency Food Security agency Forestry agency and Fishery agency
In this reporting period the project has provide technical assistance to the planner staff of above institutions to integrate CCA in the annual work plan for 2016 by using the climate risk and vulnerability map

description.narrative: Livelihoods of vulnerable rural communities strengthened in a changing climate
climate risk reduction activities introduced at local level list type and scope refer to AMAT 2211

comment.narrative: no climate risk reduction and awareness activities are introduced at local level
At least 5 types of climate risk reduction measures have been introduced in the three target districts of which at least three measures are specifically targeting women

Climate risk reduction measures have been implemented during this reporting period In order to facilitate the community proposal formulation and grant disbursement processes legal entities called Kemas ProKlim Community Group for Climate Programme were established through support of the project team and NGO partners in each of the target villages One Kemas ProKlim consists of several primary community groups in a village and carry out various CCA activities Kemas ProKlim has board at village level as well as administrative personnel that is responsible for managing grants and implementation of CCA activities Standard operating Procedure for Kemas ProKlim operation has been developed including internal control framework for fund disbursement
In this reporting period nine Kemas ProKlim from nine villages three villages per a pilot district have developed CCA proposals and fund have been disbursed In total the nine Kemas Proklim consists of 64 community groups with 64 CCA activities related to food water and livelihoods resilience covered in nine proposals Additionally 12 villages four in each pilot district are in process of establishing a Kemas ProKlim and in developing a CCA proposal facilitated by SPARC District coordinator local government and NGO partner
The approved resilience building activities that are currently financed by the project include the following
Three Kemas ProKlim in Manggarai District focus on crop diversification to gain household income women activities irrigation canal rehabilitation for rice fields production improving crop resistant variety and planting system pipeline installation for drinking water supply land rehabilitation in landslides prone area mattresses production household activities for women group and cattle fattening
In Sumba Timur district three Kemas ProKlim focus on improving rice field production good practices resistant variety annual crop diversification annual crop seedling for conservation of water catchment area and productive use crop diversification fish production clean water supply
In Sabu Raijua district three Kemas Proklim implement CCA activities in improvement of clean water supply crop diversification dry land rice production maize production and water catchment conservation

comment.narrative: currently the majority of households regard themselves as highly vulnerability to climate risks
at least 75 of the households that have implemented adaptation measures regard themselves less vulnerable to climate change related risks as a result

The implementation of CCA activities are targeting impact at household level rather than village level Based on the CCA proposals of Kemas Proklim SPARC project team is currently developing monitoring tool to measure baseline situation of the participating households in CCA activities
Three short movies describing the baseline situation in 9 pioneering villages in 3 pilot districts have been developed for advocacy and monitoring

description.narrative: National Biodiversity Planning to Support the implementation of the CBD 2011-2020 Strategic Plan in Indonesia (NBSAP)
capital of a political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration

1. Development of a national targets in response to the global Aichi Targets. 2. Status of NBSAP vis-Ã -vis the guidance in the CBD Strategic Plan (2011-2020). 3. Status of the national clearing house mechanisms (CHM) and development of the 5th national report to the UNCBD.

comment.narrative: 1. The national targets have been developed but need to be reviewed with updated data & according to the Aichi Targets. 2. NBSAP is out of date and does not consider newer guidance 3. CHM is not kept up to date and is not linked up to the CBDâ€™s global CHM networks and to other information and knowledge exchange network.

1. Target achieved in 2014. Updated National biodiversity priorities, targets and indicators in response to the Global Aichi Targets were adopted into draft IBSAP 2015-2020. 2. The updated and fully endorsed of Indonesia NBSAP by the Government of Indonesia and is submitted to the UNCBD Secretariat. Further, the updated national targets are mainstreamed into National Mid-Term Development Plan (RPJMN) 2015-2019. 3. Institutional frameworks for Indonesia NBSAP implementation is in place and Biodiversity Clearing House Mechanism (CHM) is operational as platform for knowledge exchange and targets monitoring.

1. There was changing on the Government structure after general election. Even final draft of the updated IBSAP was available in early 2015, it was advisable to adjust strategy and action plan according to new Medium-term Development Planning. Therefore, the IBSAP can't be endorsed and submitted to the UNCBD Secretariat. 2. Revised IBSAP 2015-2020 was reviewed according to the new RPJMN 2015-2019. Most of action plans and targets have been mainstreamed into sectoral development planning as well as selected regional development planning. It is a multi-years process to ensure adoption of the IBSAP into development planning. 3. Institutional framework for implementation of the IBSAP 2015-2020 has been recommended by the project. Even the IBSAP document does not legally binding, the Government and national stakeholders keen to use updated IBSAP as reference in managing Indonesia biodiversity. CHM is proposed as media to collect, share, and manage biodiversity data dan information using web-based application. However, it can be fully operationalised due to pending on data sharing agreement among relevant line ministries and relevant stakeholders. It will be finalized in 2016.

1. Updated IBSAP 2015-2020 is launched and recognized by the new Indonesia Government by early 2016. 2. Indonesia Biodiversity Clearing House Mechanism is revitalized and ready for operational. 3. Submission of the updated IBSAP 2015-2020 to UNCBD Secretariat by Dec 2016.

1. The formulation process of IBSAP has produced a vision for management of Indonesia biodiversity, â€œIndonesiaâ€™s biodiversity are maintained, developed, support the nation competitive advantages and its utilization is for the welfare of the present community and the future generationâ€. To concretize the vision, 3 (three) missions were formulated based on the policy direction to support the achievement of biodiversity management. The achievement of these aims and strategies is formulated into 22 national targets that synergizes to the national needs and global target (Aichi target). The revised IBSAP have been launched on January 21, 2016. 2. Enhancement of Indonesia Clearing-house Mechanism (CHM) website which links to Global CBD has been completed. CHM designed to meet the needs of its users, to draw lessons from the experiences of users and the resources available. CHM explore various ways appropriate to increase access to technology, technology transfer and institutional capacity (human resources, institutions and mechanisms of coordination between agencies). At the national level, in addition serves to form a network of information, CHM is also expected to facilitate the implementation of the management of biodiversity data and information. The institutional framework of Indonesian Biodiversity Clearinghouse has been established based on the Decree of the Minister of Environment and Forestry SK Number. 755 / Menlhk / KSDAE // KUM.0 / 9/2016 regarding Working Group Indonesia Biodiversity Clearinghouse. 3. The project has developed two version of the IBSAP 2015-2020 which are Bahasa Indonesia and English version. It was reviewed by expert peer with recommendations to improve the monitoring of the action plan implementation with actionable maps. The English version has been submitted to UNCBD Secretariat in Dec 2017 during the COP Meeting.
Project closed in 2016.
Project closed in 2016.

comment.narrative:
(1) BUR document is launched and submitted to UNFCCC,
(2) All local governments across Indonesia are trained to upload data and information concerning GHG inventory,
(3) Adaptation activities are identified and promoted,
(4) Mitigation actions are identified.

(1) The Ministry of Environment and Forestry softlaunched BUR on 18 September 2015 in Shangri-la Hotel for public attention.
(3) There are a number of adaptation that have been identified for detailed activities implementation (the vulnerability and impacts of Climate Change to agropolitan, honey-bee, landslides, small-island, lake area, agricultural area, etc.)

(1) 1st BUR submitted to UNFCCC
(2) Mid Term Review conducted and completed
(3) National and local institutional arrangements for GHG inventories designed and strengthened
(4) Developed National GHG inventories for 2000-2012 series using 2006 IPCC inventory guidelines
(5) Vulnerability, climate impact analysis and adaptation assessments carried out at local level in key sectors
(6) Adaptation policies and measures to address climate change are designed at the local/sectoral level and integrated into national and local planning processes
(7) Improved understanding of GHG emissions scenarios under BAU from sources and sinks; and future GHG mitigation options including their macro-economic impacts
(8) Designed GHG mitigation policies and measures at national level in the context of national action plans
(9) Indonesian Government approved Third National Communication and biennial update reports submitted to UNFCCC and relevant documents and policy briefs

(1) The Ministry of Environment and Forestry uploaded the 1st BUR to the UNFCCC website in March 2016
(2) The Mid Term Review consultant was recruited in October 2016. Stakeholders meetings and reviews were conducted at the end of November 2016. The report was submitted to UNDP in December 2016.
(3) QA/QC data up to 2012 was completed and has been uploaded to Sistem Inventarisasi Gas Rumah Kaca Nasional (or National Inventory System on Greenhouse Gases) or SIGN Center
(4) National Database for GHG Inventory up to 2012 is available (including waste management and AFOLU sectors) on SIGN Smart website
(5) The framework of adaptation policies and planning has been developed. Minister of Environment and Forestry released an Adaptation policy No. 33/Menlhk/Setjen/Kum.1/3/2016) in 2016.
(6) GHG Inventory 2000-2012 is available in SIGN SMART website: www. signsmart.menlhk.go.id and incorporated into the 1st BUR.
(6) The framework of adaptation policies and planning has been developed. Minister of Environment and Forestry released an Adaptation policy No. 33/Menlhk/Setjen/Kum.1/3/2016) in 2016.
(7) Tools and methodologies of climate change vulnerability impact assessment report has been submitted and approved.
(8) MRV report of PEP RAD GRK is available in hard copy
(9) Gap analysis on climate change policies and mitigation target has been conducted and included in BUR document; chapter 4.
(10) Analysis on technology transfer needs for mitigation actions has been conducted and included in BUR document; chapter 4. Technology Needs Assessment (TNA) report that was submitted earlier to UNFCCC became the main reference.

(1) Updated National GHG Inventory for 2000-2012
(2) Reports on the impacts, vulnerability and adaptation measures to address climate change, variability and extreme events
(3) Report on GHG mitigation policies and measures to address climate change
(4) Report on description of national circumstances and other relevant information
(5) Indonesia Third National Communication

(1) National GHG Inventory for 2000 â€“ 2012 has been published through GHG Inventory Guidebook KLH
(2) Reports on the impacts, vulnerability and adaptation measures to address climate change, variability and extreme events has been produced as part of TNC report in Chapter 5
(3) Report on GHG mitigation policies and measures to address climate change has been produced and presented in first BUR and TNC report Chapter 6
(4) Report on description of national circumstances and other relevant information has been produced. It is a part of first BUR document and TNC report Chapter 2
(5) The Third National Communication has been edited and is being translated into English.

1. Capacity development strategies and action plan developed; commenced for implementation. 2. Developed baseline forest cover in Project demonstration sites. 3. Developed operational guidelines for RBM implementation. 4. a. a small unit of intelligence based poaching & wildlife trade surveillance established and equipped; b. mechanism for monitoring, analyzing and reporting developed. 5. Technical guidelines for biodiversity, key species and habitat condition monitoring updated & disseminated to all Sulawesi PAs system. 6. Sulawesi PA system financing plan and strategies developed including proposals for broader policy reform supporting revenue generation and retention, institution arrangement, tool for cost effective management and others. 9. Study on potential financing mechanism for Sulawesi PA management. 10. Action plan for strengthening management effectiveness of the Sulawesi PA system developed. 11. Updated threats and work plan in project sites. 12. Updated RBM guidelines including biodiversity and ecosystem health monitoring. 13. Monitored of the existing condition of selected threatened species, threats, habitat and wildlife trade. 14. Fragmented and degraded ecosystem restoration conducted. 15. Existing CCAs revitalized and 5 new CCAs established.

1. Preliminary activities related to strengthening PA management conducted in the three sites. identification of the current condition of each targeted PA; coordination with associated stakeholders to avoid overlapping in project implementation; advocacy efforts to gain support from local government, communities and other stakeholders in and around target PAs. 2. Consultant worked under closed consultation and coordination with PMU, MoEF and National Park Authorities on establishing the baseline. 3. RBM trainings conducted â€“serve as baseline for drafting guidelines. Gap analysis report on existing policies and regulations for RBM, and RBM capacity and implementation needs are under development (to be finalized in December 2016.) 4. Regular patrol activities conducted; Baseline study on poaching and wildlife trade in Sulawesi is under development â€“ to be delivered in November 2016. 5. Current protocol in monitoring and reporting system of biodiversity-related data is identified; The guideline is expected to be delivered in November 2016. 6. EPASS support the establishment of new national park area in West Sulawesi â€“ Gandang Dewata. Official launching of the national park by the President Jokowi ïƒ to be conducted in October 2016. 7. The valuation is underway, conducted by consultant; The report is to be delivered by January 2017 8. Team of consultant is working on financing plan and strategies ïƒ to be finalized in March 2017 9. Team of consultant is working on financing plan and strategies ïƒ to be completed in December 2016 10. METT Assessment workshops conducted in three project sites; The project supported the enhancement and capacity of newly established Tangkoko Forest Conservation Management Unit (KHPK Tangkoko). 11. Project sites identified and continuously monitored and updated threats in the respective areas, under closed coordination and consultation with National Park and Nature Reserve Authorities; Cooperation and collaborations were established in

1.RPTNs (National Park Management Plan) updated 2. Annual forest degradation at project sites reduced by 5% from the baseline. 3. (I) Guidelines for Community engagement & Co-Management developed and (II) related trainings conducted 4. The intelligence based poaching and wildlife trade surveillance unit is fully operational at least within Project sites and buffer zones. 5. Platform for monitoring, reporting and knowledge sharing of the Sulawesi Biodiversity developed at provincial level. 6. PA System Consolidation Plan and Action plan for expansion and realignment of Sulawesi PA System be vetted by relevant districts and provinces planning authorities to be eventually integrated into their spatial planning. 7. Communication strategy to increase public awareness on the importance of biodiversity & ecosystem services provision developed. Key target groups: decision makers, local government official and local and indigenous community. 8. Business plan of the Sulawesi PA developed through participatory approach involving communities, private sector, NGOs and related government agencies. 9. Sustainable financing: An enabling policy/legal environment developed through technical meetings, consultation and consensus building at local and national level 10. Participatory Biodiversity-based boundaries realigning at project sites and buffer zone designation developed. 11. description.narrative: Enhanced systemic and institutional capacity for planning and management of Sulawesi PA system
Extent of implementation of RBM

comment.narrative: RBM has begun to be implemented at all NPs and several other PAs exact TBD but remains incomplete throughout
Using PHKA RBM scoring system see page 22 at least 70 of resorts across the island have achieved Stage 6 level of implementation

In implementing RBM NPs currently reach stage 5 in resort establishment based on definition by MoEF Officers are routinely in the resort and doing the surveillance job passive NPs in project sites already divided their areas into resorts and placed officers in each resort However there is not enough manpower with necessary capacity within the NP to perform tasks within the resort In some cases one resort only has one officer which makes it almost impossible to do the full range of tasks required from a resort
During the first year of the project RBM training was conducted to increase the effectiveness of RBM implementation in the project sites The training helped identify necessary needs and changes in the implementation in the three project sites which will be used as the base to draft RBM guidelines and analyse the gap on existing policies on the establishment of resort in NP Issues raised by the project sites include the lack of human resources and facilities needed to manage resorts
In preparing gap analysis report on existing policies and RBM operational guidelines and training the project will be supported by a series of consultant as technical support Recruitment and contracting process of the consultants were finalised in June 2016 It is expected that by the second term of the year more efforts in increasing the effectiveness of RBM implementation in the project sites will show accelerated progress

description.narrative: Operational islandwide biodiversity monitoring system

comment.narrative: No integrated monitoring
Users across Sulawesi Indonesia and beyond are able to upload to and access historic data on biodiversity and proteccted areas generated by multiple sources using a platform created by the project

An Monitoring Information System MIS Officer was hired to help establishing biodiversity monitoring system and database collection in Sulawesi under the project Related stakeholders were also invited in discussions for inputs to determine the most suitable platform for Sulawesi by making use of the existing system in KSDAE
The project hired consultants as technical support to help the establishment process of the system Several methods of data collection and monitoring system were proposed including Occupancy Survey and SMART patrol

Meetings to prepare agreement with community conservations at several buffer zone villages in Lore Lindu NP were conducted in the first half of 2016 The meeting aimed to encourage the reestablishment of community conservation group within the villages as well as establishing cooperation between Lore Lindu NP Agency with villagers owning land areas within the NP The meeting was attended by around 15 participants consisted of NP Agency staff village authorities community leaders animal care group Cakar Maleo and FCU EPASS Lore Lindu staff The initiative was enthusiastically welcomed by the community and the project will reactivate existing idle CCA left by TNC

activity-description.narrative: Mapping Surveys on the Condition of Pilot Courts and Judges with the Judicial Commission

description.narrative:
Indicators : 1.1 (1) Effective implementation of SC-JC Joint Regulation (Peraturan Bersama) and the proper functioning of the Working Committee for the improvement of a more impartial, accessible, independent, accountable and effective judiciary is established between the SC and Judicial Commission 1.1 (2) Monitoring System to share info between the internal oversight mechanism of the SC and the external oversight mechanism of the Judicial Commission is in place and implemented Annual Output Indicator: Year 1. First step to bridge SC and JC relationship is completed Year 2. Mechanism to re-activate Working Committee is implemented Year 3. Increased frequency of Working Committee meeting Year 4. Working Committee is functioning and the monitoring system/data sharing is in place Year 5. Working Committee is functioning and the monitoring system is in place
1.2 (1) Standard operating procedures and policies relating to internal oversight mechanism are in place and implemented 1.2 (2) NÂ° of external surveys conducted by CSOs based on improved instrument aimed at the development of quality improvement policies. 1.2 (3) External survey instrument to analyze the court services, jointly developed with the CSOs is enhanced and implemented Annual Output Indicator: Year 1. Comprehensive assessment report to improve SOPs and external survey is in place Year 2. Improved SOPs and external survey instruments on Internal Oversight mechanism is tested and in place Year 3. Improved SOPs and external survey instruments on Internal Oversight mechanism is implemented Year 4. Improved SOPs and external survey instruments on Internal Oversight mechanism is implemented Year 5. Improved SOPs and external survey instruments on Internal Oversight mechanism is proposed to the Supreme Court
1.3 Enhanced public complaint mechanism in pilot regions (7 or 8 pilots) to enable an investigation to be tracked and keep statistics on complaints and responses Annual Output Indicator Year 1

comment.narrative:
1.1.(1) Min.2 joint activity is conducted by the Supreme Court & Judicial Commission facilitated by the Liaison Officer; 1.1.(2) Monitoring system to share info between internal oversight mechanism, and Judicial Commission is developed
1.2. (1) Comprehensive assessment on the current internal oversight functions to support organisational transition process of the internal oversight functions is conducted 1.2. (2) Improved external survey conducted by CSOs based on the developed instrument
1.3 Comprehensive assessment to the current system for monitoring and handling complaints and coordination mechanism between the provincial and district courts and Supreme Court oversight function
1.4 N/A
1.5 Minimum 1 initiative is implemented together with the Tax Court

1.1 SUSTAIN Inception Report recommends a suspension of the implementation of joint activities between Supreme Court judges and the Commissioners of the Judicial Commission until new commissioners being appointed. The Supreme Court' perceived Judicial Commission as having no jurisdictions over judges and frequently interfere with judges' independence to make sounds judgment. The Supreme Court high ranking officials clearly stated that the Judicial Commission involvement in any program unrelated to the supervision of the conduct of the Judiciary members is perceived inappropriate.
1.2. (1)1 Training of Trainers for Supervisory judges of the Oversight Body on Case Tracking System. This application can and will be used as electronic system to conduct supervision to shorten internal oversight procedures in timing and resources. Supervisory judges do not need to check manual registrars to oversee each court the three levels of the hierarchy and this application will be soon applied to the 4 court jurisdictions. Upon attendance of the CTS training, Supervisory Judges began the use of automation system in the oversight activities although the detailed oversight automation Standard Operating Procedures and legal basis are yet to be established. This is a work in progress of the Oversight Sector. 1.2. (2) As for the external surveys, no survey has been conducted by the CSOs based on improved instrument aimed at the development of quality improvement policies
1.3. SUSTAIN Oversight Sector is currently pushing and supporting the Oversight Body (BAWAS) to discuss and to issue legal instruments drafts of public complaint mechanism which have been drafted since 2013. These new instruments, -which include the Supreme Court Regulation on Public Complaint Procedures and Whistleblowing System- are expected to overcome the lack of integrated reports from all working units in the judiciary across the four jurisdictions and discoordination among the three levels of the judicial hier

1.1. (1) Minimum 2 joint activity is conducted by the Supreme Court and Judicial Commission 1.1. (2) Monitoring system to share info between the internal oversight mechanism and the Judicial Commission is developed; 1.1. (3) Effective implementation of SC-JC Joint Regulation (Peraturan Bersama)
1.2. (1) Standard Operating Procedures and policies relating to internal oversight mechanism are in place and implemented 1.2. (2) One external survey conducted by CSOs based on the developed instrument
1.3 Coordination and reporting system to trace and monitor public complaint's handling in 7 pilot courts is developed
1.4 The target of wealth report is expanded by enactment of joint regulation or MoU between SC and Corruption Eradication Commission
1.5 Minimum 2 workshops to assess the Tax Court Model, based on the study on the Tax Dispute Settlement System are implemented.

1.1. The Supreme Court has shown its reluctance again this year to start any collaboration with the Judicial Commission. However, the Supreme Court leadership allows SUSTAIN to work together with the Judicial Commission without involving the Supreme Court. Therefore to start a working relationship, SUSTAIN is assisting the Judicial Commission by inviting a technical expert from the Conseil dâ€™Etat of France who will be one of the Speakers in the Judicial Commission Symposium to discuss comparative roles of the Judicial Commission abroad. SUSTAIN has also discussed with the Judicial Commission on possible support that SUSTAIN can provide on other programs, such as capacity building for the Judicial Commission personnel and training for judges on code of ethics. SUSTAIN is also planning to support some programs of the Working Committee between the Supreme Court and the Judicial Commission which was recently established.
1.2. (1) The FGDs that SUSTAIN has conducted to assist the Supreme Court Oversight Body (BAWAS) with the technical assistance from LeIP to gather inputs on the draft of the Supreme Court regulation about Discipline of Judges has resulted on the issuance of the Supreme Court Regulation 7/2016 on the Enforcement of Work Discipline of Judges at the Supreme Court and its Subordinate Judicial Bodies. SUSTAIN has also supported the Supreme Court in drafting the Supreme Court Regulation 8/2016 on the Oversight & Development of Direct Superiors at the Supreme Court and Its Subordinate Judicial Bodies Milieu. 1.2. (2) For the survey on public satisfaction on court services, SUSTAIN has hired a consultant to review and refine the survey instruments. By the end of 2016, SUSTAIN is in the middle of the bidding process to find a suitable institution to implement new survey based on the revised instruments.
1.3. The activities implemented for this output have led to the development of 3 (three) crucial online instruments on public complain mechanism, namely:

1.1. (1) Facilitate the Working Committee (Tim Penghubung) of the Supreme Court and Judicial Commission to improve the relationship of the two institutions (Tri-annually FGD and provision of technical assistance/ expert). 1.1. (2) Develop intermediate Training Of Trainers (TOT) modules on investigation skills (Collaborate with Indonesian National Police, Attorney General Office, and the Intelligence Agency) 1.1. (3) Capacity building (Training of Trainers) for the Judicial Commission personnel (intermediate investigation skills) 1.1. (4) Supporting the Judicial Commission's Branch Offices to map the condition of pilot courts and their judges (workload, welfare, etc.) and collaborate with the Supreme Court Human Resource
1.2. (1) Conduct Training Need Analysis for BAWAS Personnel 1.2. (2) Refreshment Training of SIPP, e-LHKPN & SIWAS for BAWAS judges 1.2. (3) Conduct trainings for BAWAS personnel on audit skills (such as Internal Personnel Auditor or APIP), including planning & budgeting 1.2. (4) Assess, conduct, and follow up on the result of Audit of Integrity
1.3. (1) Assist BAWAS to develop SIWAS Standard Operational Procedures (SOP) 1.3. (2) Conduct Sensitization/Assistance/Mentoring of SIWAS Application in SUSTAIN Pilot Courts 1.3. (3) Improvement of SIWAS Application 1.3. (4) Media development to promote SIWAS Application
1.4. (1) Conduct monitoring and Technical Assistance of Wealth Report to SUSTAIN Pilot Courts (simultaneously with other activities) 1.4. (2) Media development to promote electronic Wealth Report (e-LHKPN)
1.5. Support Chamber of Administrative Court (FGDs or Workshops) to strengthen relationship with the Tax Court (in collaboration with the 4 (four) sectors of SUSTAIN)

1.1. The Supreme Court are still reluctant to have a joint activity with Judicial Commission. However, in early 2017, SUSTAIN was given the green light by the Supreme Court to have its own activities with Judicial Commission as long as it is within the mandate of Judicial Commission. Unfortunately, due to administrative problem, SUSTAIN was only able to held one assessment on the condition of courts and judges in Makassar in 2017. SUSTAIN will continue to engage with both institutions in 2018.
1.2. SUSTAIN have conducted an assessment on the training needs required by BAWAS and follow up by performing two refreshment training of SIPP, e-LHKPN, and SIWAS usage for BAWAS judges in Jakarta and Cibinong. SUSTAIN postponed the training on audit skills in 2017 to 2018.
1.3. SUSTAIN have assisted the development of SIWAS application towards version 2.0. The new version bring more security towards the data entered to the application along with additional back-end process for BAWAS judges, such as new templates, and SOP to handle complaints. To ensure the transfer of knowledge of SIWAS, the SUSTAIN project performed sensitization and technical assistance of SIWAS application to court personnel in 11 pilot courts, and conducted two trainings for BAWAS IT Team to ensure that the maintenance of SIWAS would be performed internally by BAWAS in the future. To increase ownership of SIWAS, the project also conducted two FGDs to ensure that SIWAS application is integrated with BAWAS' internal information system. A guidebook for SIWAS application utlilization will be postponed to 2018.
1.4. The SUSTAIN project have collaborate with KPK and the Supreme Court in facilitation the sensitization of electronic wealth report (e-LHKPN) to judges under the authority of High Court of Jakarta and Yogyakarta. This sensitization event was followed by a technical assistance session towards IT staff on th etechnical aspect of e-LHKPN to ensure that those staff will be able to aid the judges and

comment.narrative:
2.1). Last TNA conducted with the Faculty of Psychology, University of Indonesia in 2010 (2010: 225) MoV: Data Sources: 2015, SUSTAIN Output 2 Rapid Assessment Report; Collection Method: Desk review
2.2) .1,296 targeted judges and/or court staff received CJE, certification or leadership training in 2014, as follows: - Continuous Judicial Education/CJE: 453 judges (2014:254); - Certification Programmes (2014:254); Environmental Certification (82 judges), Juvenile Justice Certification (245 judges), Fishery Certification (40 judges), Mediation Certification (255 judges); - Leadership Programmes (2014:260): Training Programme for Head of District Court (93 judges), Training Programme for Registrars (170 registrars); Training on Management of Training (MOT) for the Courtâ€™s training centre unit heads, senior trainers, researchers (93 persons); Training Officers Course/(TOC (170 persons); Training Facilitators Course/TFC (98 persons) MoV: Data Source: 2014 Annual Report of Supreme Court; Collection Method: Desk review
2.3). Training evaluations not undertaken, nor do they feed into performance reviews. According to the SC Annual Report, the Training Centres plans to undertake a six monthly post training evaluation for former education and training participants and an annual post training evaluation for former management and leadership training participants (2010:258).
2.4). Even though the State Administration Institute (Lembaga Administrasi Negara/LAN) and PT TUV consider the capacity of the Training Centre to be high (in 2012, LAN awarded the Centre its highest accreditation of A [valid for five years]; whilst PT TUV has certified the Centre provides training and education in line with international standards), the absence of TNA and post-training evaluation, demonstrate the Centreâ€™s capacity can be further strengthened. MoV: Data Source: Head of LAN Decree No 2811/K.I/PDP.10.4/2012, dated 14 December 2012(2012:200); and PT TUV Nord-Indonesia Cer

2.1 Training of Trainers on Adult Learning Methodology for Four Chambers of Judiciary has been successfully trained 126 Senior Judges of First Instance and appellate levels from the four chamber of the judiciary (general, administrative, religious and military judiciaries to be certified as judicial trainers. The participants of this training will be officially certified as State Trainers that will facilitate for future training in their respective chambers. This was an effort to create a new pool of trainers at the Supreme Court Judicial Training Centre.
Improvement of database at the SC Judicial Training Centre is the pre-condition of strengthening the e-learning facilities, with the process of refining the network of the Training Centre comes in between. SUSTAIN had been in a lengthy effort to recruit a qualified Individual Consultant (IC) to begin with improving the database, however such qualified individual was hard to find and a plan to utilise the in-house Supreme Court IT staff to do the work under SUSTAIN supervision is used to mitigate the risk. This approach has been found beneficial and sustainable in the case management sector during the Case Tracking System (Sistem Informasi Penelusuran Perkara) development.
2.2 The Training Needs Assessments to improve the curriculum of certification training programmes were completed for Fishery and Administrative Courts. As for the Juvenile Court, the work has been started by the establishment of Women and Children working group to accelerate the curriculum development. The subsequent action followed the curriculum development is the development of e-monev (monitoring and evaluation). The Environment Working Group carried out similar initiative; both working groups envisage the utilization of e-monev to assess the impact of the certification programmes. comment.narrative:
3.1). Currently, there has been an established Personnel Information Management System (SIMPEG) at First Instance and Appellate courts level. The Supreme Courtâ€™ plan to integrate this with - Supreme Court Information System (SIMARI) as one centralised repository database is a work in progress. The Supreme Court is progressively providing technical assistance to First Instance and Appellate courts to be able to synchronise its data into SIMARI and to utilize it to inform decisions and policy making. SIMPEG utilizes Application Programming Interface to connect four Appellate and First Instance court jurisdictionâ€™ databases. API SIMARI includes various features such as SKP (Sasaran Kerja Pegawai)- Online Employee Targets, Online Timesheet, Baperjakat Information System, Multi Reporting System, etc.
3.2). N/A

3.2. Comprehensive assessment of the existing Supreme Court database of human resources, supervision, training and other relevant source of human resource data
3.3. (1) Two technical experts provided to the Judicial Reform Office to support the implementation of Blueprints of reform; 3.3. (2) Blueprint's monev tool is developed and used

3.1 An assessment with the support of an experienced individual consultant recommends: (1) Organization of the Technical Test for new employeesâ€™ selection will include the independent party from university. (2) The necessity to determine the Guidelines of recruitment and selection system for candidate Judges and its implementation to solve the urgent shortage of Judges and Guidelines for internal promotion and working unit within Supreme Court. (3) The existing Key Performance Indicator of Civil Servants Performance Target (SKP) of all working units needs to be reviewed to have a clear measurement of individualâ€™s achievement. Moreover, the current remuneration system should be related to the individualâ€™s performance.
The Supreme Court issued the Supreme Court Regulation (Peraturan Mahkamah Agung) No.: 7 of year 2015 on the Organization and Business Process of Registrar and Secretary at the First Instance Court and Appellate Court from the four court jurisdictions throughout Indonesia. With this regulation, the position of Registrar and Secretary is now segregated. Consequently, a new functional position called "Court Staff Functional Position" (Jabatan Fungsional Pranata Peradilan) is placed under the Registrar. SUSTAIN is providing technical assistance in developing this new functional position and its credit points and to convince Ministry of Empowerment of State Apparatus (Kementerian Pendayagunaan dan Aparatur Negara) and Bureaucracy Reform to approve this functional position and the Supreme Court as the Advancement Institution of the functional position.
3.2 As mandated in the chapter XII, article 128, Law No. 5/2014 on State Civil Apparatus (Aparatur Sipil Negara), it is stipulated that the State Civil Apparatus Information System covers the entire information on state civil apparatus employee data. The Supreme Court as one of the pioneers in the implementation of Bureaucracy Reform program had successfully developed the IT based â€œPersonnel Information Sy

3.1. Minimum 2 workshops and seminars to develop policies and guidelines are conducted 3.2. Technical assistance to update and merge human resources database is provided 3.3. (1) Surveys and workshops to evaluate the implementation of the blueprint based on the developed tools; 3.3. (2) Report of Blueprint evaluation is in place

3.1. In 2016, the 5 Year Roadmap of Human Resources Management reform is ready to be proposed to the Supreme Court leadership. The Roadmap provides recommendations and the pre-conditions the Supreme Court need to build to implement a competence and performance-based Human Resources system. Three of these pre-conditons have been addressed by having three site visits and four workshops. SUSTAIN have supported the Supreme Court to establish Court Staff Functional Position, calculating the need of Human Resources/Workforce Planning (Work Load Analysis-WLA), and Identifying training needs to inform the training curriculum to increase Personnel Auditor competence.
3.2. In 2015, significant work was achieved by ensuring each working unit in Supreme Court obliged to update 100% personnel data into the Supreme Court Personnel Information System/SIKEP application. This system, thus is mandated to be the single application being used to store personnel data and non-compliance resulted in the delay of performance allowance disbursement to each working unit. In 2016, the priority is to move toward the transformation of Personnel Information System/SIKEP into a full fledge Human Resources Information System (HRIS). An FGD was conducted to arrive at common agreement to determine the future steps of this transformation.
3.3. by the end of 2016, The Australian Indonesia Partnership for Justice (AIPJ) is still working on developing the monitoring and evaluation tools to assess on the achievements of Supreme Court Blueprint 2010-2035. Once this tools have been successfully developed and approved by the Supreme Court, SUSTAIN will start doing the implementation of evaluation. Therefore, this target was not able to be performed in 2016.

The champions were able to replicate the Work Load Analysis Training for High Court personnel across Indonesia, and was even able to develop the training for analysis of Registrars and Bailiffs position. In 2016, SUSTAIN trained the champions for performing Work Load Analysis of judges. The Supreme Court planned to make the report of the Work Load analysis of all technical position by 2018. 3.1. (6). comment.narrative:
4.1). Since beginning of 2012, Case Tracking System began to be introduced and implemented in all District Courts in Indonesia. In August 2013, 350 lower courts have been utilizing CTS. The newest version of CTS, (Version 3) was launched and introduced to all lower courts and 30 high courts in Indonesia. It has been implemented in more than 70 lower courts. (http://pn-blitar.go.id/berita-terbaru/1309-memastikan-keadilan-melalui-otomatisasi) Until the end of 2013 case management system has been implemented in all court jurisdictions. General Courts use SIPP/CTS, Religious Court use Sistem Informasi Administrasi Perkara Peradilan Agama Plus (SIADPA PLUS), TUN use Sistem Informasi Administrasi Perkara Tata Usaha Negara (SIADTUN) and Military Courts use Sistem Informasi Perkara Peradilan Militer (SIADMIL) (LTMARI 2013 p.15) Per May 2015, from the Supreme Courtâ€™s Case Tracking System (CTS) database (courts of general jurisdictions) there are 6365 cases (6-12 months) and 8160 cases (more than 12 months). This figure may not be an actual number (weakness of CTS on data compliance). (http://sipp-ma.mahkamahagung.go.id/index.php). According to Supreme Court Chief of Justice Decree No 214/KMA/SK/XII/2014 dated 31 December 2014, effective 1 January 2015: maximum 8 months case handling at the Supreme Court level; Supreme Court Circular No 2 of 2014 dated 13 March 2014 applied for court of first instance (5 months) while appellate courts (3 months) (2015:12). Since 2014 the CTS (version 3) has been applied/operational at all first instance and appellate courts (general jurisdictions (2015:234). In 2014 there are 347 courts of first instance and 30 appellate courts (http://www.badilum.info/index.php/article/24/78).
4.2) There has yet to be a unified electronic case management system. Ideally those systems will be integrated into SIMARI -Terintegrasi (Sistem Informasi Mahkamah Agung Republik Indonesia â€“Terintegrasi). Currently, the CTS (SIPP) only applies to courts of

4.1. Case Tracking System Being Updated for General Court and Extended to the Military, Religious and Administrative Court
Previously, the most glaring weakness of the case tracking system was the exclusion of the Religious, Administrative and Military Courts. Other weaknesses documented within the rapid assessment report, but a few are worth sharing here: (i) Case tracking system cannot identify if parties or objects to the dispute have been involved in similar cases; (ii) it cannot automatically appoint judges to cases based on expertise, experience and workload (the manual appointment of judges in comparison is always subject to questions about objectivity); (iii) Case tracking system data including on concerned parties to the case, defendants, and convicted persons cannot be shared between courts; and (iv) Case tracking system data is inaccessible to the public. These weaknesses have been identified and given solution in the Supreme Court Case tracking system Roadmap 2015-2019.
Based on the Roadmap guidance and the Supreme Court direction, the project had extended Case tracking system development to the Administrative, Religious and Military Courts, as well as addressed some of the weaknesses of the Case tracking system through a pilot involving several district and high courts. The Case tracking system will also be integrated with other systems including the Supreme Court Personnel Information System (SIKEP), with data including the number of cases handled by, as well as the quality and consistency of justice outcomes by certain justices and judges, used to appraise their performance. The ultimate goal of this integration is to have a single court information system, the Supreme Court Integrated Information System (Sistem Informasi Mahkamah Agung RI/SIMARI).
The case tracking system version 3.1.1 has been developed by using the 4 court jurisdiction personnel for cost-efficiency and to reduce dependency to IT vendors. Sustain helps this transformation wit

4.1. In May 2016, SUSTAIN successfully launch the Case Tracking System (Sistem Informasi Penelusuran Perkara/SIPP) version 3.1.2 that integrates the 4 court jurisdictions, General Court, Military Court, Administrative Court and Religious Court cases tracking system into a unified system. As of 2016, over 2 million decisions from all regions have been published on the Supreme Court website. The annual target was achieved beyond the minimum and the Case Management sector continues to monitor the implementation of the case tracking system in each pilot court with the technical support of the regional support centres.
4.2. There is still work to be done in the finalisation of the Standard Operating Procedures to process cases involving vulnerable groups such as women and children. However, series of FGDs had been conducted and stakeholders have reached an agreed form of the Juvenile Court model. Activities to promote collaboration amongst law enforcement agencies involved in the juvenile cases have produced Agreed Work Plans between related agencies. By May and June 2016, the Juvenile Court model was launched in Kupang and Stabat district state courts. Additionally, SUSTAIN is supporting the Supreme Court in developing the electronic monitoring and evaluation system (e-monev) to measure the effectiveness of the juvenile certification programme for judges.
4.3. In 2016, SUSTAIN identified that both the Supreme Court and Ministry of Finance have similar but separate IT policy. Supreme Court insisted that all case-related data and information should be processed through the Case Tracking System/SIPP belong to the Supreme Court and consequently, the Tax court need to comply with this. However, Ministry of Finance, which supervise the Tax Court, also insisted that administrative matters, including all kinds of information system needs to follow the Ministry of Financeâ€™ internal policy. The latest meeting between the two institutions has agreed to bring this up to the top

4.1. (1), (2), (3), and (4) SUSTAIN achieved results beyond the planned targets in 2017 on the development of SIPP application. SUSTAIN planned a minor development to develop SIPP towards version 3.1.6. However, due to the enthusiasm of the Supreme Courtâ€™s SIPP and SUSTAIN team, SUSTAIN had successfully facilitated a major development of SIPP towards version 3.2.0 instead. The new SIPP version was believed to be a major improvement and may be able to change some business process within courts. There are four major improvements in SIPP version 3.2.0, those improvements were: 1) Additional insertion of 470 document templates for court procedures. The finalization of the templates were held through an FGD in February 2017; 2) Improvement of the Online System for Inter-Court Summon Assistance; 3) Data Integration with SIAP (Case Management System in Cassation Level) and Decision Directory/Direktori Putusan. The data integration was a successful result of SUSTAINâ€™s advocacy through a discussion in Bekasi on February 2017; 4) Addition function for Juvenile Justice: Diversion registry, Registry for children under 12, Registry for Juvenile Witness and Victim. The development of SIPP version 3.2 was held in Bandung on April-May 2017. Further to the development, the project also facilitated a mentoring session by the Supreme Courtâ€™s SIPP Development Team to courts in five areas (Bandung, Kepanjen, Malang, Kabanjahe, and Medan) to check on their adoption of SIPP 3.2. In November 2017, the Supreme Court announced that SIPP version 3.2.0 should be ready and installed to all courts by 1 January 2018. 4.1. (5) SUSTAIN facilitated two discussions in Bandung (May and August 2017) on the development of an umbrella IT policy within the Supreme Court. The discussions have produced a draft policy and guidelines on IT within the Supreme Court. The approval of this policy will continue in 2018 by the Supreme Court. 4.1. (6) The project supported the comprehensive self-assessment of SIPP

Office Premises and Inauguration The agreement between the Government of Indonesia and the European Union calls for the provision by the Supreme Court of adequate premises to host SUSTAIN Project technical assistance team. The ongoing construction of additional offices and court buildings for various services of the Supreme Court and for some of its subsidiary courts â€“in particular the Jakarta Administrative Appellate Court (Pengadilan Tinggi TUN)â€”has delayed the availability of office space for SUSTAIN Project. Consequently, SUSTAIN office moved to four difference locations. UNDP country office, World Trade Centre II service office, Supreme Court Secretariat building 11th floor and lastly in the third Quarter of 2015, SUSTAIN finally secured the office location at Supreme Court Secretariat building on the 12th floor. The renovation was completed in November 2015 followed by the inauguration on November 24th 2015.
Recruitment of Personnel The position of Communication Analyst began her tenure in December 2015- following the termination of the position Communication and the decision to upgrade this position into an Analyst position- as per project objectives and donor imperative to push for the implementation of an effective communication strategy and visibility.

comment.narrative: 1.1. No technical by-laws and guidelines on PBDE handling and management. 1.2. No national standard on the maximum use of PBDEs in a product. 1.3. No EPR scheme for PBDE containing product groups. 2.1.No technical guidelines on the plastic production and recycling 2.2. No checking has been undertaken to identify PBDEs in both virgin and recycled, raw materials. 3.1.1 Unavailability data on gender-based recyclers. 3.1.2 No plastic recyclers have capacity to identify PBDE and process plastic waste. 3.1.3 No application of BAT/BEP in plastic recycling activities. 3.2.1 No data on PBDE containing plastics. 3.2.2Technical guidelines to separate PBDE containing plastics. 4.1. Limited number of demonstrated mini-depos in urban areas. 4..2 10 tons/week of waste is dumped in Surabaya River. About 3 tons is dumped in Cikapundung River weekly. 4.3 Bandung has more than 1,000 tons a day of waste is being landfilled. 750 tons/day is not collected. Surabaya generates 2,400 tons MSW. 1,200 tons/day landfilled. 5. No M&E and adaptive management applied to project in response to project need. 6. No Project Management Unit is established.
Project Document was signed and start implementation in March 2016.

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - policy, planning and administration

1.1. Reports on GHG Abatement cost curve analysis of power generation and energy intensive industries. 2.1. Rules, regulations, and procedures on MRV 2. 2. Institutional set up for MRV 2.3. Capacity building and awareness raising activities for sectoral MRV system in power and energyintensive industries 3.1. Map of MRV activities at the installation level in Indonesia. 3.2. Monitoring protocols. 3.3. Data management system at the installation level. 3.4. GHG emission data and review on the MRV system at the installation level and at an aggregated data management level. 4.1. Comprehensive assessment report on MBI options for Indonesia 4.2. Design of selected market-based instruments for the selected sector. 4.3. Draft policy(ies) required for establishment and implementation of MBI. 4.4. Piloting the market-based instrument in the selected sector. 5.1. Market readiness communication and information tool. 5.2. Stakeholders awareness and capacity of MBI options for climate change mitigation. 5.3. Stakeholders involvement in MBI discussion.

comment.narrative: 1.1 The National Council on Climate Change developed a national GHG abatement cost curve covering, inter alia, power and cement sectors (2014). 2.1 Presidential Decree No. 71/2011 obliged sectoral MRV (2011). 2.1 Draft Ministry of Industry regulation on GHG Emissions Reporting (2015). 2.2 Unclear structure on MRV Institution at central/national level 2.3 No known capacity building activities in sectoral MRV area (2016). 3.1 No known mapping of MRV activities at the installation level in Indonesia (2016). 3.2 No assessment on existing protocols and its suitability for Indonesian context in power and energyintensive industry sectors (2016). 3.3 No standardized data management systems at the installation level issued by the Government (2016). 3.4 No sectoral GHG emissions data are available for public; No review on MRV system at the installation level as itâ€™s not yet established (2016). 4.1 Ministry of Finance released an Australia-supported Green Paper which recommends economic and fiscal policy strategies for climate change mitigation in Indonesia. Carbon pricing in form of carbon tax/levy is the recommended MBI for energy sector in that Green Paper (2009). 4.2 There was a comprehensive design of a domestic crediting mechanism developed by the late National Council on Climate Change (DNPI). The crediting mechanism was called Nusantara Carbon Scheme and was in preparation to do piloting when DNPI is disbanded. The NCS is not pursued anymore by the GoI and currently there is no other MBI design existed in Indonesia (2015). 4.3 Currently there is no policy that establish an MBI in Indonesia (2016). 4.4 Currently there is no MBI in piloting stage in Indonesia (2016). 5.1 One publication in carbon trading basics were issued by DNPI in 2013 and currently there is no other local reference for carbon market and MBI. 5.2 Awareness and capacity of MBI options are generally low (2016). 5.3 Stakeholders constructive and active participation in MBI discussion is genera
N/A - the project started in 2017
N/A - the project started in 2017

Output 1. A Consulting Firm to conduct the study and development of GHG emission profiles in the power and energy-intensive industry sectors is selected through a fair and competitive process, involving the government counterparts.
Output 2. 1. Draft regulations on sectoral MRV for power and energy-intensive industries; 2. Draft regulations on sectoral MRV for power and energy-intensive industries; 3. 2 (two) capacity building events in implementing monitoring reporting and data management systems
Output 3. 1. Site level assessment to map MRV activities at the installation level in Indonesia is conducted. 2. TOR for assessment of monitoring protocols is developed. 3. TOR for development of data management system is developed.
Output 4. 1. Experts/company hired to develop comprehensive report on MBI options for Indonesia. 2. Experts/company hired to develop comprehensive design of an MBI agreed by the stakeholders, including necessary procedures and guidelines. 3. TOR developed on assistance to draft policy(ies) required for the establishment and implementation of MBI. 4. TOR developed to pilot MBI in selected sectors
Output 5. 1. 1 (one) briefing paper on MBI principles; 2. 4 (four) quarterly newsletters on MBI and PMR activities; 3. 2 (two) booklets on MBI principles; 4. Other PMR activitiesâ€™ information materials. 5. 1 (one) questionnaire to stakeholders in MBI related issues

Output 1. TUV Nord Indonesia (in association with AMC), has been selected, and contract signed on 1 October 2017. (The duration of the work is 8 months, and targeted to be completed in June 2018. Final Report is expected in July 2018.)
The study is on-going. Several working group discussions within industry and power WG are on-going. FGD for power, food & beverage, chemical, fertilizer, textile, ceramic & glass and cement sectors have been conducted throughout Nov-Dec 2017.
First draft report of sector profile have been submitted to CMEA, including compilation of activity data from the sectors (company level).
Output 2. 1. The following drafts is being developed by GoI: Draft of MEMR Minister Regulation on Energy Sector GHG Inventory; Draft of GHG Inventory Guidelines for Power Sector; Draft of MoI Minister Regulation on Cement GHG MRV System; Draft of GHG MRV Guidelines for Fertilizer Industries; and Draft of MoI Minister Regulation on National Industry Information System / SIINAS (including GHG information).
The 2nd and 4th one is mainly supported by PMR and preliminary complete drafts is expected in January 2018.
2. 2 (two) capacity building events on MRV and Data Management were conducted in June and August 2017.
Output 3. 1. Site level assessment for cement industry is conducted in Indocement plant, Cirebon, 11-13 October 2017.
2. Elements of necessary works to assess the existing/possible monitoring protocols is being identified and discussed within the corresponding WGs. In addition, a TOR to assess monitoring using Continuous Emissions Monitoring System (CEMS) is developed in December 2017.
3. Elements of necessary works to develop data management system is being identified and discussed within the corresponding WGs. The draft GHG Inventory Guidelines for Power Sector is addressing this area to some extent.
